fields.description:
Setting hostname verification with reflection breaks under JDK 7:

{code}
Caused by: java.lang.NoSuchMethodException: sun.security.ssl.SSLSocketImpl.trySetHostnameVerification(java.lang.String)
	at java.lang.Class.getMethod(Class.java:1622)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.ssl.LdapHostnameVerificationSSLSocketFactory.makeUseLdapVerification(LdapHostnameVerificationSSLSocketFactory.java:80)
{code}

Change this to work using the JDK7 support for setting this through {{SSLParameters}}.
fields.summary: SSLSocketImpl.trySetHostnameVerification breaks under JDK 7

fields.description:
We have a group called "app-blueprint-ham". These group didn´t have any direct members. Only another group "Domänen-Benutzer" ( our first dc was a german dc :-( ) is member of the "app-blueprint-ham" group.
All of our staff people are direct members of this group. If i open the group "app-blueprint-ham" in crowd, only a few nested members are shown and opening the group "Domänen-Benutzer" didn´t work. (see attached screenshots).

Also the authentication via a crowd client is denied for members of "Domänen-Benutzer", if this group is added as described above. If i choose a group that didn´t contain german umlauts everything works very well as expected (for testing i have used staff).
fields.summary: groupnames with german umlaut didn´t working properly

fields.description:
CWD-2106 means Crowd can build with Maven 3. Supporting multiple versions of Maven for the full release process causes too many silent failures: configuration that's essential in one version may be ignored in another.

[~rmedellin]'s work has shown that a full release works with minimal changes. We should move the build to use, and require, Maven 3.
fields.summary: Move build to Maven 3
ApplicationServiceGeneric.searchUsers does not correctly handle several directories
it's not possible to start Crowd from outside the Crowd install directory
CrowdService.updateUser(...) causes "Write operations are not allowed in read-only mode" error

fields.description:
h3.How to Reproduce:
# Create 2 groups in LDAP:
#* Group1
#* Group2 
# Assign membership attributes to each Group as per below:
#* Group1
#** member: Group2
#** member: UserA
#* Group2 
#** member: UserB
# Set up a Delegated Authentication Directory in Crowd, with the *Use Nested Groups* and *Sync Group Memberships* options checked
# Login to Crowd using UserB (Notice that only Group2 is synced, Group1 is not synced even though Group2 is child of Group1). 
# Login with UserA this time (Notice that Group1 is also synced now, but if you try to check on the Nested Members of Group1, you'll find that only UserA is a Nested/Direct Member of Group1. What happened to UserB? UserB is only a member of Group2. 

This indicates that the Nested Groups functionality of Delegated Authentication Directory does not really work at all.
fields.summary: Nested Groups do not work with Delegated Authentication Directory
Check and fix internal URLs pointing to wac

fields.description:
Right now Crowd uses ldapmodify for managing user passwords. Is there any chance to change this behaviour to let ldappasswd do that?
Ldappasswd takes advantage of any overlays like ppolicy or smbk5pwd. The last one allows user to synchronize samba passwords via Crowd SSO service.
fields.summary: Crowd ldappasswd for OpenLDAP

fields.description:
Asked as question in answers.atlassian.com with no response other than the one from the customer that claims this is an issue with the authenticator. However, the authenticator is using ConfluenceAuthenticator and Atlassian APIs to login and the login audit data is logged correctly in the old DB tables used prior to Crowd.

I asked for assistance to developer relations and Ben Speakmon said to create a ticket in Jira in Crowd for it to get support since it was beyond them.

Thanks in advance!

Here is more info on the issue:

The custom Confluence authenticator that displays the issue (note: we are not asking for support with the authenticator- just trying to figure out why it isn't logging data to the table):
https://studio.plugins.atlassian.com/svn/SHBL/tags/2.0.1/src/main/java/shibauth/confluence/authentication/shibboleth/RemoteUserAuthenticator.java

answers.atlassian.com entry:
https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/21460/how-to-update-logininfo-table-in-confluence-4-0-in-custom-confluence-authenticator

Related authenticator ticket:
https://studio.plugins.atlassian.com/browse/SHBL-50

Related Confluence ticket that customer closed because he claimed was authenticator issue, although I do not know what the authenticator is supposed to do to get the filter to update the table with username data:
https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONF-24033
fields.summary: Confluence 4.0.x does not update LOGININFO via embedded Crowd correctly when using custom authenticator
Connection tests use pooled connections with different settings

fields.summary: Memberships are not imported from JIRA 4.4.3

fields.description:
h3.Description
When there is a Group Name Attribute change in Delegated Authentication Directory, instead of updating an existing group's name to use the new attribute, Crowd creates another group with that alternate Group Name (So there will be some sort of a duplicate group).

h3.How to Reproduce
# Create a user, with cn=UserA in LDAP.
# Create a group, with cn=GroupA, description=GroupAcopy, member=cn=UserA in LDAP 
# Set up a Delegated Auth Directory in {{Crowd Console >> Directories >> Add Directory}} to sync Group memberships, and assign the *Group Name Attribute* to *cn*.
# Login as UserA into Crowd, which will automatically create the group, GroupA in Crowd as well.
# Update the *Group Name Attribute* in the Delegated Auth Directory Configuration in Crowd to *description*, this time.
# Login as UserA again

Notice that there will be another group called GroupAcopy created in Crowd, with the old group, GroupA still there (2 groups instead of 1). Expected behavior would be that Crowd will update GroupA to GroupAcopy (since it's a name attribute change).
fields.summary: Group Name attribute change behavior in Delegated Authentication Directory

fields.description: Uses the query SELECT usr FROM InternalUser usr, InternalMembership mem WHERE usr.id = mem.childId AND mem.lowerParentName = ? AND mem.membershipType = ? AND mem.directory.id = ? AND mem.groupType = ? which doesn't guarantee any particular order, so one you start using startIndex and maxResults you get inconsistent results.
fields.summary: MembershipDAOHibernate.search returns users in indeterminate order

fields.description:
Hello there,

as described in CWD-1709 it is not correctly possible to import users and especially memberships from Jira, when Crowd and Jira is using an Oracle 11g-Database.

Szenario:
Create a new directory called: Jira-Atlassian-Test
Now go to: Users --> Import Users --> Atlassian Product Importer

Choose:
Product: Jira
Directory: Jira-Atlassian-Test
Import Passwords: does not care
DB-Connection: Jira's 11g-Database-Connection

--> Continue

Result:
{quote}
The import is now complete. If there were any users or groups that failed to import please consult the log files for more information. 

Users imported: 143

Groups imported: 505

Group Memberships imported: 181
{quote}

First: Only 181 Memberships with 505 Groups?
Second: The connected Jira-System has: 857 total user(s), 505 Groups and much more memberships!

Info: Both are connected to an LDAP-Server and it is irrelevant if i use the ldap-directory or an internal one.

Here is the log - nothing interesting :-(.

fields.summary: Atlassian Importer is not working correctly with Oracle 11g

fields.description:
Currently groups will be synced upon a login of a groupmember.
Groups that do not contain any members (but subgroups) will not be synced.
Crowd should also fetch the parent groups of a group when adding it to the directory.

Example Use Case #1:
Group A members: Group B, Group C
Group B members: User Foo
Group C members: User Bar

Group B and C do exist. But Group A does not exist in Crowd.
And now I want to add permissions/restrictions in Confluence for Group A.

Example Use Case #2:
Group D members: User Foo, Group E
Group E members: Group F
Group F members: User Bar

Group D and F do exist. But Group E does not exist in Crowd.
And now I want to add permissions/restrictions in Confluence for Group D.
But those permissions won't apply to the members of group F, as the chain is interrupted (Group E is missing).

Compare to CWDSUP-5870
fields.summary: LDAP Delegate: Also sync parent groups

fields.description: TBD
fields.summary: Prevent Crowd from filling the connection pool with requests to an unavailable LDAP server

fields.description:
ResetPasswordListener responds to certain types of password reset events by sending notification email, but fills in its template with the wrong properties. It's called indirectly by DirectoryManagerGeneric.resetPassword, which is deprecated.

The resulting email doesn't include the new password or a reset link so its only use is to notify.

We should note that this method will no longer cause email to be sent and remove the listener.
fields.summary: Remove com.atlassian.crowd.event.listener.ResetPasswordListener

fields.description:
Add the following line to the crowd.xml to stop Tomcat from persisting session data between restarts.

<Manager pathname=""/>
fields.summary: Stop crowd's Tomcat distribution from attempting to persist sessions between restarts

fields.description:
The AD integration by default will try to use an incremental sync. For this to work we need two things:

# The user needs to be able to read uSNChanged attributes. 
# The user needs to be able to access Deleted Objects container.

If either of these conditions is not true incremental sync will not work. At the moment Crowd silently just blindly assumes both of these conditions hold and tries to do an incremental sync even though it might not be working.

Crowd should detect if either of these conditions does not hold, and warn the user in some way. For example, during the connection test it could say that "Incremental Update is not possible....". Crowd might even rollback to doing a full sync if it detects that either of these conditions is not true.
fields.summary: Crowd needs to detect when an incremental Update is not possible and react

Customers have seen this error in their logs JIRA:

It is occurring because the user used in the sync does not have permission to see the  uSNChanged attribute.

This is kinda interesting because it indicates that "incremental sync" will not work because the user does not have the correct permission.
fields.summary: USNChangedMapper throws NPEs if AD does not return the uSNChanged attribute

fields.description:
Trying to update the 'Delegated Auth' directory type results in a error "There was an error in updating the directory. Please check the fields to ensure all entries are valid."

h4. Steps to reproduce
* Create a *Delegated Authentication Directory*
* Go through the steps to setup the Detail/Connection
** do *not* select option to *Synchronise Group Memberships*
* On the Configuration tab, press update
* Error:
!delegated error.jpg|thumbnail!
** This occurs whether or not you've made any changes

Looking over the crowd source we found that the Delegated Auth directory is still checking for group related fields even though this should not be the case.

h4. Workaround
* enable *Synchronise Group Memberships*
fields.summary: Error Updating the Configurations for Delegated LDAP Auth

fields.description:
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] com.atlassian.crowd.model.authentication.ValidationFactor@13fe59df[name=remote_address,value=0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1%0]

should be comparing on
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] com.atlassian.crowd.model.authentication.ValidationFactor@13fe59df[name=remote_address,value=0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1]

that is, without the %0.
fields.summary: IPv6 token comparisons should filter out the interface

fields.description: Disabling roles in the connector configuration does not actually do anything. The roles tab is visible for users of the directory and the ldap queries for the roles are run. If you don't enable the roles and insert a "sane" value for the role DN then the roles will be queried with just the base DN which in our case results in slow performance as user details will only open after the search times out when browsing individual users in the directory.
fields.summary: Cannot disable roles for Sun DSEE directory connector

fields.summary: Calling the REST endpoint GET /rest/crowd/1/directory/xxxx will throw a NPE if the directory has never performed a synchronization.

fields.description:

fields.description:
Many OpenID implementations (including Gerrit 2.1.7) are developed based on the newer openid4java 0.9.6 to fix a security issue with 0.9.5, which requires servers to sign attributes to prevent them from being forged. 

The following is an error thrown when attempting to login to Gerrit with Crowd OpenID:
{code}
[2011-10-05 17:46:24,014] WARN / : Unexpected error during authentication
org.openid4java.message.MessageException: 0x100: Namespace declaration for extension http://openid.net/sreg/1.0 MUST be signed
at org.openid4java.message.Message.getExtension(Message.java:495)
{code}

We have to repackage and test Crowd OpenID with the latest version of the openid4java. Crowd currently ships with openid4java-0.9.5, we would need to test it with 0.9.6.
fields.summary: Upgrade Crowd's openid4java client to 0.9.6

fields.description:
When users are created as part of external directory synchronisation, it would be nice if there was a way to determine this from the event fired.

In Studio, users can be created from three sources: manual creation from the UI, creation as part of synchronisation with Google, and creation as part of synchronisation with an external directory. In the first case, application access is granted according to the choices made by the creating admin. In the second case, default application access is granted when the user first logs in. In the third case, however, currently no application access is granted, leaving the users unable to login with the manual intervention of an administrator.

Allowing us to determine that a UserCreatedEvent was fired due to external directory synchronisation creating a user would allow us to assign default application access to users in this third situation. Note that simply assigning default access to a user on receipt of a UserCreatedEvent would not work, as the users created by Google synchronisation for customers with large Google domains would exhaust their application license counts.
fields.summary: Ability to distinguish creation events for synchronisation-created users

fields.description:
A feedback from our customer:

{quote}
I think the documentation which is currently (within http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Importing+Users+from+Atlassian+JIRA):

>> 'Database Driver' — Type the name of your JIRA instance's database JDBC driver (e.g. for MYSQL, type com.mysql.jdbc.Driver).

should be expanded (via link to another page if necessary) so that the user can easily find the relevant driver entry for their JIRA database, and just copy and paste it in to the form. That would avoid both guesswork and typos.
{quote}

From this page (http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Importing+Users+from+Atlassian+JIRA), the values of 'Database Driver' should have a list available for reference. Some of the users may not aware what kind of database driver should they put. It would be great if we could have a different sample for reference. For example, not only show the sample for MySQL but other database driver as well (e.g. MS SQL, postgres, Oracle and etc).
fields.summary: Update the doc to show a list of sample database JDBC driver

fields.description:
When an user is not authorised to authenticate against an application, some REST end points inconsistently throw the checked exceptions {{ApplicationPermissionException}}, {{InvalidAuthenticationException}} or {{ApplicationAccessDeniedException}}, sometimes in opposition to what their javadocs say.

Examples, to authenticate the same user against the same application:
* _com.atlassian.crowd.service.client.CrowdClient.authenticateSSOUserWithoutValidatingPassword()_ calls {{/session?validate-password=false}}, which returns a 403, which throws an {{ApplicationPermissionException}} to the caller (due to _{{RestExecutor.MethodExecutor.throwError()}}_). Whereas, according to the javadoc, it should throw {{ApplicationAccessDeniedException}}: "if the user does not have access to authenticate against the application")
* _com.atlassian.crowd.service.client.CrowdClient.authenticateUser()_ throws {{ApplicationPermissionException}} for the same error (since {{/authentication}} returns a 400, which throws a {{CrowdRestException}} which then caught and re-throw as an {{InvalidAuthenticationException}} with the username) 
* _com.atlassian.crowd.integration.http.CrowdHttpAuthenticator.authenticate()_ {{com.atlassian.crowd.exception.InvalidAuthenticationException}} for the same problem (which calls {{ /session?validate-password=true}} and returns a 403, which throws an {{ApplicationPermissionException}} to the invoker) 

This complicates the code invoking the CrowdClient and CrowdHttpAuthenticator.
fields.summary: Inconsistent exceptions thrown in REST client when an user can not authenticate against an application
The CrowdDirectoryService.synchroniseDirectory is not very useful
DirectoryManagerGeneric.synchroniseCache is not thread safe

fields.description:
When we do a restore in JIRA we try to stop any long running tasks. Currently there us no way for JIRA to wait for Crowd synchronizations to finish. This can lead to JIRA failing during the restore with random reasons. For example, we can get Unique Index Errors from the DB because the Crowd Sync is trying to write data at the same time JIRA is restoring data.

We need an API that allows us to both wait for any currently running synchronizations to stop and to stop any other syncrhoizations from starting (e.g. shutdownAndWait). For extra points, it would be nice if it was possible to interrupt/stop the sync before it is finished.
fields.summary: There is no way to shutdown Crowd Embeded on JIRA Shutdown

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 8 June 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hello everyone,

We have recently reviewed this issue and the overall interest in the problem. As the issue hasn't collect votes, watchers, comments, or support cases from many customers during its lifetime, it's very low on our priority list, and will not be fixed in the foreseeable future. That's why we've decided to resolve it as *Timed Out*.

Although we're aware the issue is still important to those of you who were involved in the conversations around it, we want to be clear in managing your expectations. The Crowd team is focusing on issues that have broad impact and high value, reflected by the number of comments, votes, support cases, and customers interested. Please consult the [Atlassian Bugfix Policy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/support/atlassian-server-bug-fix-policy-201294573.html] for more details.

We understand how disappointing this decision may be, but we hope you'll appreciate our transparent approach and communication.

Atlassian will continue to watch this issue for further updates, so please feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

Thank you,

Crowd Team
{panel}
 
In my local dev instance, I spun up a fresh Crowd instance with an LDAP connector and no other modifications.  When trying to access the site using http://hostname:port/crowd as a local admin account, the login page would appear to refresh.  When accessing using localhost in place of my hostname, it worked as expected.

After some debug logging on com.atlassian.crowd, it turns out that my username/password was accepted, but the crowd_token.key wasn't being respected when the 302 redirect to the Crowd landing page was sent.  Since the token wasn't respected, it sent me another 302 redirect to the login page, which gave the appearance of a page refresh with no error.

Logging in using the localhost URL and disabling database token caching allowed me to login from the hostname URL.
fields.summary: Database token caching causes login errors

fields.description: Our documentation on [integrating crowd with Apache on Windows|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD020/Installing+the+Crowd+Apache+Connector+on+Windows] stipulates that we support only activeperl 5.8 and 5.10. Now that activestate provide only free version of 5.12 while the archive downloads are only available with commercial license. It will be nice if we can provide support for the free community license to allow our users the opportunity to integrate with Apache. This is a blocker for most users at the moment.
fields.summary: ActiveState no longer provides ActivePerl 5.10 community license

fields.description:
When we are trying to add a user as a member of a groups we receive the following message on the menu

*No results found matching the search criteria.*

!AddUsers.png|thumbnail!

When we have multiple users that span out more than one page, the provided message made us think that the users is not migrated yet or does not exist. Eventually we found out that the users is already listed as a member, however this really waste our time to confirm that the user is already listed.

After some research I found out the following lines on the responsible JavaScript. The lines seems to confirm that Crowd only search the non member groups.

*{{view_group_members.jsp}}*
{code}
CROWD_PICKER.attachPicker("addUsers", "<ww:property value="getText('picker.addusers.label')"/>",
                    "<ww:url namespace="/console/secure/pickers" action="searchPicker" method="getUserNonMembersOfGroup" includeParams="none" escapeAmp="false"><ww:param name="directoryID" value="directoryID"/><ww:param name="entityName" value="groupName"/></ww:url>",
                    "<ww:property value="getText('picker.addselected.users.label')"/>",
                    "<ww:url namespace="/console/secure/group" action="updatemembers" method="addUsers" includeParams="none" escapeAmp="false"><ww:param name="directoryID" value="directoryID"/><ww:param name="entityName" value="groupName"/></ww:url>",{code}

In order to avoid this confusion, it would be a lot better if Crowd search the whole user list and provided a clear indication whether the searched user is not exist, or already a member of the group
fields.summary: When user is already listed as a member the message display during add member to a group menu should be clear

fields.description:
Crowd 2.3.3 seems to have a problem syncing user memberships from LDAP (using Connector). 

h3.Tests:
I personally tested this with Apache Directory Server 1.5, using the same settings as my LDAP connector in Crowd 2.1.1 (which is working fine). I tried enabling and disabling *Node Referrals*, *Nested Groups*, *Use the User Membership Attribute*, *Use Paged Results*, *Naive DN Matching*, and made sure that I configured the user and group as well as membership attributes according to my Crowd 2.1.1 settings that works fine. Nothing seems to work, groups and users are pulled accordingly, but memberships are not.

h3.Log output:
{code}
2011-10-05 14:23:47,440 scheduler_Worker-4 INFO [atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteDirectory] synchronisation for directory [ 32770 ] starting
2011-10-05 14:23:47,661 scheduler_Worker-4 INFO [directory.ldap.util.DirectoryAttributeRetriever] Unsafe or Blank attribute value for attribute <mail>: ' '.

Several times a day, a series of exceptions appear on the log file, and after those, Crowd stops authenticating:

2011-10-03 11:55:04,990 http-8080-2 INFO [ContainerBase.[Catalina].[localhost].[/crowd]] Initializing Spring FrameworkServlet 'xfire'
2011-10-03 11:55:12,233 http-8080-4 ERROR [org.hibernate.jdbc.AbstractBatcher] Exception executing batch: 
org.hibernate.StaleStateException: Batch update returned unexpected row count from update [0]; actual row count: 0; expected: 1

Complete log files are attached.
fields.summary: Crowd stops authenticating after StaleStateException when executing batch

fields.description:
Crowd preallocates arrays of {{max-results}} at the start of LDAP queries unless the size is {{EntityQuery.ALL_RESULTS}}. If a client sends a huge value for this, to indicate that they don't care about batching, this will exhaust memory.

Switch to always allocating collections with their default sizes and growing them as necessary.
fields.summary: Don't preallocate arrays for LDAP queries

fields.description: Crowd uses its own crowd-integration-springsecurity in its web interface. If this is upgraded to Spring Security 3 either we need to keep the Spring Security 2 version around or Crowd needs to be upgraded.
fields.summary: Upgrade Crowd to Spring Security 3.0

fields.description:
The logging of error messages that are received in the REST response from Crowd by the RestCrowdClient doesn't make it clear that the error message is coming from the remote system. This is confusing and is leading to issues in support where it's hard to figure out what exactly is going on in which system.

An example from a recent FishEye support case. The customer opened a support issue with FishEye logs in which it appears that FishEye has run out of heap space:

{noformat}
com.atlassian.crowd.exception.OperationFailedException: Java heap space
        at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.rest.service.RestCrowdClient.handleCommonExceptions(RestCrowdClient.java:1084)
        at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.rest.service.RestCrowdClient.getNamesOfNestedUsersOfGroup(RestCrowdClient.java:677)
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.crowd.CrowdAuth$6.call(CrowdAuth.java:405)
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.crowd.CrowdAuth$6.call(CrowdAuth.java:403)
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.crowd.CrowdAuth.withTimer(CrowdAuth.java:92)
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.crowd.CrowdAuth.getUsersInGroup(CrowdAuth.java:403)
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.DefaultUserManager$16.write(DefaultUserManager.java:1057)
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.DefaultUserManager$16.write(DefaultUserManager.java:1050)
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.config.DB0Handle$2.write(DB0Handle.java:122)
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.config.DB0Handle.write(DB0Handle.java:96)
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.config.DB0Handle.write(DB0Handle.java:120)
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.DefaultUserManager.getUsersInGroup(DefaultUserManager.java:1050)
        at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
        at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)
        at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)
        at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:597)
        at org.springframework.aop.support.AopUtils.invokeJoinpointUsingReflection(AopUtils.java:309)
        at org.springframework.aop.framework.JdkDynamicAopProxy.invoke(JdkDynamicAopProxy.java:196)
        at $Proxy25.getUsersInGroup(Unknown Source)
{noformat}

While it is actually Crowd that has run out of heap space and is letting FishEye know what is wrong. A lot of confusion could have been avoided if the log had simply said: *Error message from Crowd: Java heap space*
fields.summary: Improve logging of remote exceptions in RestCrowdClient

fields.description:
Hello, I'm developing an app that talks to crowd 2.2.2 rest api. I noticed that a post to the following rest api resource returns 204 regardless of whether the email is found in the system: 

/rest/usermanagement/latest/user/mail/usernames?email=valid_email => returns 204
/rest/usermanagement/latest/user/mail/usernames?email=invalid_email => returns 204, but should return 404 according to the documentation here: https://developer.atlassian.com/display/CROWDDEV/Crowd+REST+Resources. 

I'm sure this is extremely low priority, and I can work around by first searching for the email to see if I get any search results. But just wanted to let you all know about the minor bug. 

Thanks!
- Dave
fields.summary: Crowd 2.2 Rest API resource /user/mail/usernames?email=EMAIL always returns 204 status

fields.description:
We had a situation where a customer's user DN (FedoraDS) was configured to "ou=people" but in Crowd we had "ou=People".

This caused login failure and it took us almost a week to find out what was wrong.

Ideally we should have a better authentication test like Trevor's: https://extranet.atlassian.com/display/~tcampbell/Embeded+Crowd+Troubleshooting+Page (as suggested by Joseph W).

And on the failed test, list out the search filter or DN that failed in the GUI.

fields.description:
One of the {{Import-Package}} directives in {{crowd-rest-application-management}} is:

bq. com.google.common*;version="[1.0,2.0)"

This makes it difficult for JIRA to upgrade from google-collections to guava, since guava release numbers are r06, r08, etc.

Removing the {{,2.0)}} should fix this.
fields.summary: Crowd Import-Package requires com.google.common version=[1.0,2.0)

fields.description:
From Scott McCulley,


I ran in to some difficulties during the install of Crowd.  I thought I might bring them up to as something to address in your next release.

1)  During the configuration of the default admin, the application attempts to resolve the hostname of the server.  If it fails, it reports error.  But before it does, it adds the user and group to the DB so it is impossible to re-use that admin user or create a new one, since the group already exists.

Question:
{noformat}
Is it really necessary to attempt to resolve the hostname of the server?  What if (and I am) using a different name to access Crowd, and it isn't the name of the server??
{noformat}

Suggestion:
{noformat}
1)  Ask for the name of the server (actually, I think you do.)  Then use that server name instead of attempting to use the hostname.
2)  Don't create the user if you intend to fail.  Or if you fail, drop the user from the DB, so it can be re-used later.
3)  Same goes for the admin group as well...
{noformat}


Error log:

{noformat}
2011-09-18 19:34:20,050 http-8095-1 INFO [console.action.setup.SelectSetupStep] Current setup step is /console/setup/directoryinternalsetup.action
2011-09-18 19:34:24,651 http-8095-1 INFO [console.action.setup.SelectSetupStep] Current setup step is /console/setup/defaultadministrator.action
2011-09-18 19:34:46,700 http-8095-1 ERROR [console.action.setup.DefaultAdministrator] web3.cardboard-box.com: web3.cardboard-box.com
java.net.UnknownHostException: web3.cardboard-box.com: web3.cardboard-box.com
        at java.net.InetAddress.getLocalHost(InetAddress.java:1360)
        at com.atlassian.crowd.console.action.setup.DefaultAdministrator.addCrowdApplication(DefaultAdministrator.java:213)
        at com.atlassian.crowd.console.action.setup.DefaultAdministrator.doUpdate(DefaultAdministrator.java:112)
        at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
        at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)
        at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)
        at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:597)
{noformat}

fields.description:
Logging in "fails" using chrome.  Using chrome, at the login screen "console/login.action", after submitting the correct user name and password the login screen simply reloads w/ empty fields for username / password.  If you enter incorrect credentials, the correct error message "Invalid Login" pops up above the login fields.

I cannot recreate this error in FF 6 or IE 9.

fields.description:
Currently Crowd import from CSV file [can only work|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Importing+Users+from+CSV+Files] with a set of default fields.

This feature will be made more useful if admin is allowed to import custom fields. eg. address, telephone number, etc.
fields.summary: Allow custom field import from CSV file

fields.description: Very good Application
fields.summary: Testing Jira

fields.description: Once a user has a valid SSO token from successfully logging in to an application, if they are then removed from the groups permitted to use that application they will still be able to login until that session expires.
fields.summary: Crowd SSO sessions allow access after a user is removed from a group until session expires

fields.description:
{{crowd-administrators}} logged in as a normal user on first login in Delegated LDAP directory in Crowd 2.3.2

This was raised by a customer testing on Crowd 2.3.2

Upon further investigation we noticed that this only affects the first login.

Subsequent logins allowed the LDAP user to access administration functionality again.
fields.summary: crowd-administrators logged in as a normal user on first login in Delegated LDAP directory in Crowd 2.3.x

fields.description:
When a user first authenticates against {JIRA, FECRU, Confuence or Bamboo}, the user's credential are correctly validated and the user is automatically added to the local Crowd cache for that directory.

However, the other Atlassian servers do not have the new user's credential in their local user directory information. Hence, the user login fails on JIRA, etc. and the user is given a system error message.

The problem is self corrected within an hour typically as the other Atlassian servers synchronize their user directories and pick up any incremental user and group information since the last sync.

This should be done automatically when a new user is added to the local Crowd cache for all applications which are using Crowd authentication.
fields.summary: Crowd doesn't create new users automatically in other directories when he first login, but after sometime

fields.description:
When deploying the current crowd WAR to jetty, crowd serves all contents as "text/html". All current browser releases ignore css files with a mime type of "text/html" which leads to an destroyed layout of the User Console.

However, this error does not occur with the standalone release of crowd as Tomcat seems to correct this bug by overriding the mime types.

Looks like a Filter is setting wrong mime types for all served files...
fields.summary: Wrong MIME types lead to uninterpreted css stylesheets
error while deleting user from crowd.

fields.description:
The default value of {{0}} for {{session.validationinterval}} leads to poor performance. As the documentation says, it means that every single incoming request to the application will need to make at least one request out to Crowd. Currently when using SSO (i.e. the Crowd authenticator) it makes 2 connections to Crowd per request. One to validate the SSO token and one to get the SSO cookie configuration (see CrowdHttpAuthenticatorImpl#isAuthenticated) Since Confluence does this in a filter, it means even requests to fetch CSS, JS and other resource files make 2 requests. I measured the dashboard in Confluence 3.3 make 38 requests to Crowd in a single page load.

We should really change the default value in the bundled properties file (and update the documentation) to a non-zero value so it looks up the user from the session until the validation interval is reached.
fields.summary: Default value of 0 for session.validationinterval leads to poor performance

fields.description:
The Apache HttpClient used by Crowd's REST client by default only makes at most 2 connections to the same host. This can be overridden by calling the {{setMaxConnectionsPerHost}} method. Currently the Crowd client only calls {{setMaxTotalConnections}}, which sets the size of the pool, but does not raise the limit on the maximum number of connections to each host. Since the Crowd host is always the same, this effectively means we have a connection pool size of 2 to Crowd. This leads to poor performance, especially in environments where {{session.validationinterval}} is set to {{0}}

h3. Resolution
Upgrade the Crowd REST client to 2.3.3 or above.

h3. Patch
If you are unable to upgrade for some reason, then use the attached patched Crowd 2.2.8 REST client.
fields.summary: http.max.connections is not respected by the Crowd REST client

fields.description:
We have Jira 4.3.4 set up to authenticate against an internal directory in a remote Crowd instance. The remote Crowd server is 2.2.7.
If I change someone's email address in the internal directory on the Crowd server, and then re-synchronize the user directory on the Jira server, the email remains the same in Jira rather than changing
fields.summary: update to email address does not synchronize with crowd embedded in Jira

fields.description:
Similarly to JIRA or AD crowd should log failed authentication attempts.

Administrator could use it to troubleshoot authentication problem or brute-force attacks.
fields.summary: Crowd does not produce logs for user's failed authentication in remote application

fields.description:
[Installing the Crowd Apache Connector on Windows|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD020/Installing+the+Crowd+Apache+Connector+on+Windows] currently suggests ActivePerl 5.10 which has now been replaced by 5.12. Old ActivePerl releases are only available under a commercial contract.

For customers who do not wish to take on a support contract we should verify the steps under ActivePerl 5.12 and also see whether other Perls ([Strawberry Perl|http://strawberryperl.com/] or [Cygwin|http://www.cygwin.com/]) are acceptable.
fields.summary: Investigate free options for Perl Crowd connector

fields.description:
On many places dropdowns are used to select a certain directory, group or user. If your Crowd instance has many directories and groups with a bit longer, but describing, titles those drowdowns are unreadable. This makes them a bit useless because you don't have any idea what you're adding. (see screenshot).

Problem seems to be in IE only, because Firefox and other browsers handle selects a bit different. But in a corporate environment where IE is still very common, crowd becomes a pain to work with.
fields.summary: dropdowns not readable with long directory and groupnames

fields.description:
Crowd seems to be affected by the following problem during application syncs, whereby calls to java.lang.Class.getInterfaces() consumes a high amount (~80%) of the CPU:
https://forum.hibernate.org/viewtopic.php?p=2404651

Quoting the above thread:
{quote}
Hibernate seemed to be spending a lot of time in each query checking if the loaded entities were dirty and in need of flushing.
{quote}

The above user was able to bypass this performance problem by passing a query hint "org.hibernate.readOnly".
fields.summary: Hibernate performs unnecessary dirty-checking, eating up high CPU

Despite that the import appear successful above, the session has already invalidated as it reached beyond Tomcat's default *session-timeout* - causing the import to fail unless the session-timeout is extended.

We should fix the error message to reflects the real state of the import, thus marking this as a bug.

h4. Workaround
Extend Tomcat's session timeout: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWDKB/Unable+to+Import+Users+Into+a+Directory+Due+to+Tomcat+Session+Already+Invalidated
fields.summary: Import failed despite being reported is finished due to 'Session already invalidated'

fields.description:
crowd-integration-client is using package 'com.atlassian.ip' which should be reserved for the atlassian-ip library.

This means that the OSGi subsystem does not know which version to export 'com.atlassian.ip' at, and causes the following log messages:

{noformat}
2011-08-19 17:48:51,063 main WARN      [org.twdata.pkgscanner.ExportPackageListBuilder] Package Scanner found duplicates for package 'com.atlassian.ip' with different versions.
 Files: crowd-integration-client-2.3.2.jar and atlassian-ip-2.0.jar
  '/media/SSD1/src/atlassian/jira/atlassian_jira_4_4_branch/classes/artifacts/jira/WEB-INF/lib/crowd-integration-client-2.3.2.jar'
  '/media/SSD1/src/atlassian/jira/atlassian_jira_4_4_branch/classes/artifacts/jira/WEB-INF/lib/atlassian-ip-2.0.jar'
{noformat}

fields.description:
Hi,

if there are any connection problems between Crowd and LDAP (e.g. cannot connect, connection slow) you have to browse the logs. I had cases where I had to increase logging level in order to see anything.

So I am requesting a new page within the webfrontend: System-Health. This page could show attributes like
* LDAP/RemoteCrowd connection state/latency
* average time required for an user-auth with LDAP
* user-auth-queries per minute/hour
* tail of the logs?
* ...
fields.summary: System-Health page that shows connection problems with LDAP

fields.description:
When using the Crowd Rest API to update a user one can send an xml message like this to activate a user:

{code:xml}
<user name=USERNAME>
  <active>true</active>
</user>
{code}

This update will succeed leaving the user in an invalid state:

- The email address is empty
- The first name is empty
- The last name now contains the username

I suggest the following fixes:

- Make sure you can never leave a user in an invalid state. In this case I would expect another status_code
- Not providing a field should not result in emptying it when updating.
fields.summary: Updating a user using Crowd REST API can leave user in invalid state

fields.description: The documentation of the [User Resource|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWDDEV/Crowd+REST+Resources#CrowdRESTResources-UserResource] in the Crowd REST Api is incorrect. The update of a user {{/user?username=USERNAME}} returns a 204 instead of a 200(OK) as stated in the docs when the update is successful.
fields.summary: Crowd REST API documentation incorrect

fields.description:
This is an enhancement of existing Crowd feature which allows to include a successfully authenticated user to the specified groups. 

Having
user1 to be included in group1 upon successful login in Jira (or any atlassian application)
user2 to be included in group2 upon successful login in Jira

In crowd I have
directory1 which includes user1 in group1 upon a successful login
directory2 which includes user2 in group2 upon a successful login

The request is to have something like

http://crowd/jira/dir1 which would login a user in jira upon successfully authenticated against dir1. This login operation would include user in group1 as configured in crowd for dir1

http://crowd/jira/dir2 which would login a user in jira upon successfully authenticated against dir2. This login operation would include user in group3 as configured in crowd for dir2

The rationale of this request is to be able to include users in different groups automatically, with no management involved. This is currently available for crowd, but it's limited to be able to add a user in a single group since the login to jira is a single point of access. This request is allowing multiple point of access to a tool _through_ crowd:

http://crowd/jira/dir1
http://crowd/jira/dir2
etc.

which would allow to specify different groups a user would be included upon a successful authentication.

This request is the result of CWDSUP-5337
fields.summary: Add new users to different groups upong login depending on the crowd url used

fields.description:
I am in a situation where we have Crowd querying multiple Active Directory servers as delegated authorities. In many instances we have users with the same name in multiple directories, but with different passwords in each. The situation that we encounter is that a user will enter a password for a particular directory, but Crowd will fail their login if it queries a directory in which their password is different. 

My suggestion is that after a failed authentication attempt against the first directory a name match is found in, Crowd should continue to query all of the remaining directories that are configured for the application.
fields.summary: Continue to query subsequent directories after failed login attempt.

fields.description:
Steps to Reproduce
Given Crowd 2.2.7 + mod_authnz_crowd-2.0.2.tar.gz + Apache 2 
1. Set up a generic application connected to 1 directory with allow all to authenticate = false.
2. Create a simple group in directory, no members in this group.
3. Configure application to only allow this group to authenticate to application.
4. Use any user that is in the directory to authenticate to apache.

Expected behavior:
Crowd should return 403 forbidden- Authentication passed, but not allowed.

Actual behavior:
Crowd returns 500 Internal Server Error.

From Crowd log:
{code}
2011-08-11 09:42:25,974 http-6095-8 DEBUG [crowd.manager.application.ApplicationServiceGeneric] User does not have access to application 'foo' as the directory is not allow all to authenticate and the user is not a member of any of the authorised groups
{code}

From Apache Log:
{code}
[Thu Aug 11 09:42:24 2011] [error] [client 192.168.15.79] Unexpected status code: 403
[Thu Aug 11 09:42:24 2011] [crit] [client 192.168.15.79] Crowd authentication failed due to system exception
(END) 
{code}
fields.summary: Crowd Apache Connector incorrectly returns 500 when user is not authorized but can authenticate

fields.description:
Customers usually have two set of instances on their environment, each for production and QA purposes.

Some company would prefer to set their environment for both QA and production on the same domain. However this would result to signing out the others set of instances when a user log-in to the other set of instances.
fields.summary: One domain use by multiple Crowd should not blocked the SSO function
